questions.text: What is/are the minimum antenatal visits required for a pregnant woman as per MCH?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

 

According to MCH guidelines, at least four antenatal visits are recommended for every pregnant woman to ensure maternal and fetal well-being.

 

  • According to Park's Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, and guidelines under the Maternal and Child Health Programme, a minimum of 4 antenatal care (ANC) visits is essential for early identification and management of pregnancy-related complications.
  • The recommended schedule of visits is:
    • First visit: Before 12 weeks (preferably as early as possible)
    • Second visit: Between 14-26 weeks
    • Third visit: Between 28-34 weeks
    • Fourth visit: Between 36 weeks and term
  • These visits ensure:
    • Screening for high-risk pregnancies
    • Immunization (e.g., tetanus toxoid)
    • Iron and folic acid supplementation
    • Birth preparedness and complication readiness
    • Fetal monitoring and health education

choices.text: Give a dose of TT & explain to her that it will not protect the newborn & she should take the second dose after 4 weeks even if she if delivers in the mean time
Do not waste the TT vaccine as it would anyhow be of no use in this pregnancy
Given one dose of TT, explain it will not be useful for this pregnancy
Give anti-tetanus immunoglobulin along with the TT vaccine

questions.text: A 37-week pregnant woman visits the antenatal clinic at a Primary Health Centre (PHC) for the first time. She has not received any antenatal care or tetanus immunisation during the pregnancy so far. What is the best approach regarding tetanus protection for her and her newborn?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

At 37 weeks, a single TT dose will not confer adequate neonatal protection, but it should still be given along with advice to complete the second dose after 4 week

  • The standard TT immunisation schedule for a previously unvaccinated pregnant woman is:
    • TT-1: As early as possible in pregnancy
    • TT-2: At least 4 weeks after TT-1, and minimum 2 weeks before delivery to protect the newborn
    • TT-Booster: If previously fully immunised in the last 3 years
  • In this case, since she presents at 37 weeks and hasn't received any TT dose:
    • TT-1 must be given immediately, even though it won't protect the baby (as 2 weeks are required post-TT2 for antibody transfer).
    • She must be informed that the second dose (TT-2) should still be taken after 4 weeks, even if delivery occurs before that, to ensure her future tetanus protection.
  • Note: There's no indication to give tetanus immunoglobulin in this situation unless it is a tetanus-prone wound or exposure.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida from a low-income background attends the antenatal clinic. During her check-up, it is noted that her weight gain during pregnancy is significantly below normal standards. On average, what is the typical weight gain during pregnancy in a poor Indian woman?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The average weight gain in a poor Indian woman during pregnancy is approximately 6.5 kg, which is lower than the recommended amount due to nutritional and socioeconomic factors.

  • The recommended weight gain in pregnancy for a healthy woman is 11-13 kg, depending on pre-pregnancy BMI.
  • However, due to nutritional inadequacy, poverty, and poor antenatal care, the average weight gain in a poor Indian woman is found to be around 6.5 kg.
  • This suboptimal weight gain increases the risk of:
    • Low birth weight (LBW)
    • Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)
    • Maternal morbidity and mortality
  • Hence, it is essential in public health to provide nutritional support, such as IFA tablets, supplemental food through ICDS, and proper antenatal monitoring.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lactating mother visits the health center for postnatal counseling. She is exclusively breastfeeding her 2-month-old infant. As per the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) recommendations, what is the additional daily energy requirement during the first 6 months of lactation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

During the first 6 months of exclusive breastfeeding, a lactating mother requires 600 kcal/day of additional energy to meet both her and the infant's nutritional needs.

  • As per Park's PSM, 27th Edition, and ICMR 2020 recommendations, the additional energy requirement during lactation is:
    • First 6 months (exclusive breastfeeding): +600 kcal/day
    • 6-12 months (partial breastfeeding): +520 kcal/day
  • This increased requirement accounts for the energy cost of milk production, which is around 85 kcal per 100 mL of breast milk.
  • On average, Indian women produce about 850 mL/day in the first 6 months.
  • Adequate caloric intake during lactation is essential to:
    • Adequate caloric intake during lactation is necessary to:
    • Maintain maternal health
    • Ensure adequate quantity and quality of breast milk
    • Prevent maternal weight loss and nutrient depletion

questions.text: What is the term used for babies born as a result of retarded intrauterine foetal growth?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Babies with weight below the 10th percentile for gestational age due to intrauterine growth restriction are termed small for date (or small for gestational age) babies

  • A small for date baby (also called small for gestational age, SGA) refers to a term infant (≥37 weeks) whose birth weight is below the 10th percentile for that gestational age.
  • This typically results from intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR) due to:
    • Placental insufficiency
    • Maternal malnutrition
    • Hypertension or preeclampsia
    • Infections
    • Smoking, alcohol, or drug use during pregnancy
  • In contrast, preterm refers to gestational age <37 weeks, and low birth weight (LBW) refers to <2.5 kg regardless of gestational age. Therefore, not all LBW babies are small for date, and not all small for date babies are preterm

Explanation of other options:

Preterm babies (Option A):Defined by gestational age <37 weeks, not by weight relative to gestational age.

LBW babies (Option B):Defined by birth weight <2.5 kg, irrespective of gestational age; includes preterm and small-for-date babies.

Retarded babies (Option D): Obsolete and inappropriate term; not used in modern medical practice for ethical and scientific reasons.

questions.text: For international comparison, the WHO expert committee defines stillbirth as the birth of a dead and underweight foetus, more than
questions.solution:
Explanatio:

For international comparison, WHO defines stillbirth as the birth of a dead fetus weighing ≥1000 grams, or ≥28 weeks of gestation if weight is unknown.

  • The WHO expert committee has standardized the definition of stillbirth for international comparability as:
    • Birth of a dead fetus with a birth weight of ≥1000 grams, or if birth weight is unavailable, a gestational age of ≥28 weeks, or a crown-heel length of ≥35 cm.
  • This definition ensures consistency across countries with differing healthcare capabilities.
  • However, individual nations may have their own legal or operational definitions (e.g., India considers ≥28 weeks gestation regardless of weight for stillbirth reporting).

questions.text: High-risk infants include all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Birth order 2 is not considered a high-risk factor, whereas twins, underweight babies, and infants of working mothers are

  • High-risk infants are those more likely to suffer from morbidity, mortality, or developmental problems, and therefore need closer monitoring and care.
  • Common high-risk categories include:
    • Low birth weight (LBW) or very low birth weight (VLBW) infants
    • Multiple births (e.g., twins, triplets)
    • Preterm babies
    • Infants of mothers with medical illnesses, malnutrition, or inadequate antenatal care
    • Infants born to working mothers or teenage mothers
    • Birth order ≥4 (increased risk with high parity)
  • However, birth order 2 is considered normal parity and is not associated with increased risk in itself.

Explanation of other options:

Twins (Option A): High-risk due to increased chances of prematurity, LBW, and perinatal complications.

Underweight (Option B): LBW infants (<2.5 kg) are universally considered high-risk.

Working mother (Option C): Infants of working mothers may face feeding issues, reduced maternal contact, and environmental stress, placing them at higher risk.

questions.text: What is the minimum number of antenatal visits currently recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

WHO currently recommends a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve maternal and perinatal outcomes.

  • As per the 2016 WHO Antenatal Care Model, the recommended minimum number of ANC contacts was increased from 4 to 8 to enhance the quality of care and reduce perinatal mortality, and improve maternal satisfaction.
  • The updated schedule includes:
    • First contact: Before 12 weeks
    • Second & third contacts: At 20 and 26 weeks
    • Fourth to eighth contacts: At 30, 34, 36, 38, and 40 weeks
  • This recommendation is aimed at:
    • Early detection and management of pregnancy complications
    • Timely immunization and supplementation
    • Education and psychological support
    • Improved communication and satisfaction with care
  • This update is under global standards, while noting that India still follows a 4-visit model under MCH services.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman visits the antenatal clinic for preconceptional counselling. Her first child was born with a neural tube defect. She is now planning her second pregnancy. What is the recommended daily folic acid dose for this woman?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Women with a previous child affected by a neural tube defect should receive 4 mg/day of folic acid, starting at least 1 month before conception.

  • Women with a history of neural tube defect (NTD)-affected pregnancy are at a higher risk of recurrence in subsequent pregnancies.
  • To reduce this risk, a high dose of folic acid (4 mg/day) is recommended.
  • Key points:
    • Supplementation should begin at least 1 month before conception and continue through the first trimester (i.e., first 12 weeks of gestation).
    • This higher dose is necessary because women with previous NTDs may have metabolic or genetic predispositions that require greater folate levels to ensure proper neural tube closure.
  • In contrast, low-risk women are advised to take 0.4 mg/day as standard preconceptional care.
  • 1 mg is Insufficient for high-risk women. It can be considered for moderate-risk cases but not after a previous NTD.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about colostrum
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Colostrum is rich in protein and immunoglobulins, but it contains less fat and sugar compared to mature breast milk.

  • Colostrum is the first milk secreted by the mother during the initial 2-3 days postpartum.
  • It plays a vital role in neonatal immunity and nutrition.
  • Key features:
    • Color and consistency: Thick, yellowish due to high beta-carotene content (Option A ruled out)
    • Protein: High, especially in immunoglobulins like secretory IgA (Option B, C ruled out)
    • Immune factors: Contains leukocytes, lactoferrin, and growth factors
    • Volume: Small in quantity but nutritionally concentrated
    • Fat and sugar: Lower than in transitional or mature breast milk
    • Laxative effect: Helps in the passage of meconium and reduces neonatal jaundice

choices.text: No injection of TT but antitetanus serum 1500 units at 36 weeks

questions.text: A 26-year-old second gravida woman attends the antenatal clinic for a routine check-up. Her last delivery was 2 years ago, during which she received both doses of tetanus toxoid (TT). What is the appropriate schedule for tetanus immunisation during the current pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

If a woman was fully immunised in a previous pregnancy within the last 3 years, only a single booster dose of TT is required during the current pregnancy.

  • In antenatal care, the tetanus immunisation schedule is designed to protect both the mother and the newborn.
  • If a woman has received two valid doses of TT during a previous pregnancy within the last 3 years, she is considered already protected.
  • In such cases:
    • A single booster dose of TT is given between 28-36 weeks, ideally around 32-34 weeks, to maintain protective antibody levels.
    • If more than 3 years have passed, the full 2-dose TT schedule is repeated.
    • Tetanus immunoglobulin or antitetanus serum is not indicated in antenatal prophylaxis.

questions.text: Under the national programme for prophylaxis against nutritional anaemia, every pregnant woman should be given 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid per day for at least for how many days during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pregnant women are advised to take iron and folic acid supplementation for at least 180 days during pregnancy to prevent nutritional anaemia

  • As per national guidelines, under the Prophylaxis Against Nutritional Anaemia Programme, all pregnant women-regardless of haemoglobin status-are given:
    • 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid,
    • Once daily for at least 180 days during pregnancy
    • Followed by 180 days postpartum, especially in lactating mothers
  • The 180-day duration ensures:
    • Adequate iron stores are built up
    • Prevention of maternal anaemia
    • Better fetal growth and reduced risk of low birth weight
  • In anaemic women (Hb <11 g/dL), the dose is doubled to 120 mg iron + 500 mcg folic acid twice daily.

choices.text: Biweekly supplementation of iron and FA to 6-60 months of age
Biweekly supplementation of iron and FA to pregnant and lactating women
Biweekly supplementation of iron and FA to adolescent girls
All of the above are parts of the initiative

questions.text: Which of the following components are included under the National Iron Plus Initiative (NIPI) for prevention and control of iron deficiency anemia in India?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The National Iron Plus Initiative targets all age groups, including children, adolescents, and women, with iron and folic acid supplementation schedules tailored to each group

  • The National Iron Plus Initiative (NIPI) is a comprehensive strategy to prevent and treat iron deficiency anemia across life stages.
  • It was launched to replace earlier fragmented programmes and includes six beneficiary groups:
    • Children 6-60 months
      • 1 mL syrup (20 mg elemental iron + 100 mcg folic acid) biweekly
    • Children 5-10 years
      • Tablet with 45 mg iron + 400 mcg folic acid weekly
    • Adolescents 10-19 years (both girls and boys)
      • Tablet with 60 mg iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly
    • Women of reproductive age
      • Weekly supplementation
    • Pregnant and lactating women
      • Tablet with 60 mg iron + 500 mcg folic acid daily for 180 days during pregnancy and 180 days postpartum
    • Others (e.g., school dropouts) are under outreach strategies
  • The programme follows both prophylactic and therapeutic approaches using oral iron-folic acid supplementation, deworming, and nutrition education.

questions.text: A 'term baby' is defined as a baby born after how many completed weeks of gestation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A term baby is defined as one born between 37 completed weeks and less than 42 completed weeks of gestation.

  • Gestational age is classified based on the number of completed weeks at the time of delivery:
    • Preterm: <37 completed weeks
    • Term: From 37 completed weeks to less than 42 weeks
    • Post-term: ≥42 completed weeks
  • A term baby is thus one delivered on or after 259 days (37 weeks) but before 294 days (42 weeks) of gestation, regardless of birth weight.
  • This classification helps in planning neonatal care and anticipating risks.
